trans-unit.source: Author Custom R Modules in Azure Machine Learning | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Author Custom R Modules in Azure Machine Learning | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Quick start for authoring custom R modules in Azure Machine Learning.
trans-unit.target: Quick start for authoring custom R modules in Azure Machine Learning.

trans-unit.source: This topic describes how to author and deploy a custom R module in Azure Machine Learning.
trans-unit.target: This topic describes how to author and deploy a custom R module in Azure Machine Learning.

trans-unit.source: It explains what custom R modules are and what files are used to define them.
trans-unit.target: It explains what custom R modules are and what files are used to define them.

trans-unit.source: It illustrates how to construct the files that define a module and how to register the module for deployment in a Machine Learning workspace.
trans-unit.target: It illustrates how to construct the files that define a module and how to register the module for deployment in a Machine Learning workspace.

trans-unit.source: The elements and attributes used in the definition of the custom module are then described in more detail.
trans-unit.target: The elements and attributes used in the definition of the custom module are then described in more detail.

trans-unit.source: How to use auxiliary functionality and files and multiple outputs is also discussed.
trans-unit.target: How to use auxiliary functionality and files and multiple outputs is also discussed.

trans-unit.source: A custom module is a user-defined module that can be uploaded to your workspace and executed as part of an Azure Machine Learning experiment.
trans-unit.target: A custom module is a user-defined module that can be uploaded to your workspace and executed as part of an Azure Machine Learning experiment.

trans-unit.source: A custom R module is a custom module that executes a user-defined R function.
trans-unit.target: A custom R module is a custom module that executes a user-defined R function.

trans-unit.source: R is a programming language for statistical computing and graphics that is widely used by statisticians and data scientists for implementing algorithms.
trans-unit.target: R is a programming language for statistical computing and graphics that is widely used by statisticians and data scientists for implementing algorithms.

trans-unit.source: Currently, R is the only language supported in custom modules, but support for additional languages will be added in future releases.
trans-unit.target: Currently, R is the only language supported in custom modules, but support for additional languages will be added in future releases.

trans-unit.source: Custom modules have first-class status in Azure Machine Learning in the sense that they can used just like any other module.
trans-unit.target: Custom modules have first-class status in Azure Machine Learning in the sense that they can used just like any other module.

trans-unit.source: They can be executed with other modules, included in published experiments or visualizations.
trans-unit.target: They can be executed with other modules, included in published experiments or visualizations.

trans-unit.source: Users have control over the algorithm implemented by the module, the input and output ports to be used, the modeling parameters, and other various runtime behaviors.
trans-unit.target: Users have control over the algorithm implemented by the module, the input and output ports to be used, the modeling parameters, and other various runtime behaviors.

trans-unit.source: A custom module is only available in the workspace in which it was created and cannot be published to community experiments.
trans-unit.target: A custom module is only available in the workspace in which it was created and cannot be published to community experiments.

trans-unit.source: A custom R module is defined by a .zip file that contains, at a minimum, two files:
trans-unit.target: A custom R module is defined by a .zip file that contains, at a minimum, two files:

trans-unit.source: A source file that implements the R function exposed by the module
trans-unit.target: A source file that implements the R function exposed by the module

trans-unit.source: An XML definition file that describes the custom module interface
trans-unit.target: An XML definition file that describes the custom module interface

trans-unit.source: Additional auxiliary files can also be included in the .zip file that provide functionality that can be accessed from the custom module.
trans-unit.target: Additional auxiliary files can also be included in the .zip file that provide functionality that can be accessed from the custom module.

trans-unit.source: This option is discussed below.
trans-unit.target: This option is discussed below.

trans-unit.source: This example illustrates how to construct the files required by a custom R module, package them into a zip file, and then register the module in your Machine Learning workspace. The example zip package and sample files can be downloaded from <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: This example illustrates how to construct the files required by a custom R module, package them into a zip file, and then register the module in your Machine Learning workspace. The example zip package and sample files can be downloaded from <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Consider the example of a Custom Add Rows module that modifies the standard implementation of the Add Rows module used to concatenate rows (observations) from two datasets (data frames).
trans-unit.target: Consider the example of a Custom Add Rows module that modifies the standard implementation of the Add Rows module used to concatenate rows (observations) from two datasets (data frames).

trans-unit.source: The standard Add Rows module appends the rows of the second input dataset to the end of the first input dataset using the rbind algorithm.
trans-unit.target: The standard Add Rows module appends the rows of the second input dataset to the end of the first input dataset using the rbind algorithm.

trans-unit.source: The customized CustomAddRows function similarly accepts two datasets, but also accepts an additional Boolean swap parameter as an input.
trans-unit.target: The customized CustomAddRows function similarly accepts two datasets, but also accepts an additional Boolean swap parameter as an input.

trans-unit.source: If the swap parameter is FALSE, it returns the same data set as the standard implementation.
trans-unit.target: If the swap parameter is FALSE, it returns the same data set as the standard implementation.

trans-unit.source: But if the swap parameter is TRUE, it appends rows of first input dataset to the end of the second dataset instead.
trans-unit.target: But if the swap parameter is TRUE, it appends rows of first input dataset to the end of the second dataset instead.

trans-unit.source: The file that implements the R CustomAddRows function exposed by the Custom Add Rows module contains the following R code.
trans-unit.target: The file that implements the R CustomAddRows function exposed by the Custom Add Rows module contains the following R code.

trans-unit.source: To expose this CustomAddRows function as an Azure Machine Learning module, an XML definition file must be created to specify how the Custom Add Rows module should look and behave.
trans-unit.target: To expose this CustomAddRows function as an Azure Machine Learning module, an XML definition file must be created to specify how the Custom Add Rows module should look and behave.

trans-unit.source: Note that the value of the id attributes of the Input and Arg elements in the XML file must match the function parameter names of the R code exactly (dataset1, dataset2, and swap in the example).
trans-unit.target: Note that the value of the id attributes of the Input and Arg elements in the XML file must match the function parameter names of the R code exactly (dataset1, dataset2, and swap in the example).

trans-unit.source: Similarly, the value of the entryPoint attribute of the Language element must match the name of the function in the R script exactly (CustomAddRows in the example).
trans-unit.target: Similarly, the value of the entryPoint attribute of the Language element must match the name of the function in the R script exactly (CustomAddRows in the example).

trans-unit.source: In contrast, the id attribute for the Output elements do not correspond to any variables in the R script.
trans-unit.target: In contrast, the id attribute for the Output elements do not correspond to any variables in the R script.

trans-unit.source: When more than one output is required, simply return a list from the R function with results placed in the same order as outputs are declared in the XML file.
trans-unit.target: When more than one output is required, simply return a list from the R function with results placed in the same order as outputs are declared in the XML file.

trans-unit.source: Save these two files as CustomAddRows.R and CustomAddRows.xml and then zip them together into a CustomAddRows.zip file.
trans-unit.target: Save these two files as CustomAddRows.R and CustomAddRows.xml and then zip them together into a CustomAddRows.zip file.

trans-unit.source: To register them in your Machine Learning workspace, go to your workspace in the Machine Learning Studio, click the +NEW button on the bottom and choose MODULE -> FROM ZIP PACKAGE to upload the new Custom Add Rows module.
trans-unit.target: To register them in your Machine Learning workspace, go to your workspace in the Machine Learning Studio, click the +NEW button on the bottom and choose MODULE -> FROM ZIP PACKAGE to upload the new Custom Add Rows module.

trans-unit.source: The Custom Add Rows module is now ready to be accessed by your Machine Learning experiments.
trans-unit.target: The Custom Add Rows module is now ready to be accessed by your Machine Learning experiments.

trans-unit.source: The Module element is used to define a custom module in the XML file.
trans-unit.target: The Module element is used to define a custom module in the XML file.

trans-unit.source: Multiple modules can be defined in one XML file using multiple module elements.
trans-unit.target: Multiple modules can be defined in one XML file using multiple module elements.

trans-unit.source: Each module in your workspace must have a unique name.
trans-unit.target: Each module in your workspace must have a unique name.

trans-unit.source: Register a custom module with the same name as an existing custom module and it will replace the existing module with the new one.
trans-unit.target: Register a custom module with the same name as an existing custom module and it will replace the existing module with the new one.

trans-unit.source: Custom modules can, however, be registered with the same name as an existing Azure Machine Learning module and it will appear in the Custom category of the module palette.
trans-unit.target: Custom modules can, however, be registered with the same name as an existing Azure Machine Learning module and it will appear in the Custom category of the module palette.

trans-unit.source: Within the Module element, you can specify an optional Owner element that is embedded into the module as well as a Description element which is text displayed in quick help for the module and when you hover over the module in the Machine Learning UI.
trans-unit.target: Within the Module element, you can specify an optional Owner element that is embedded into the module as well as a Description element which is text displayed in quick help for the module and when you hover over the module in the Machine Learning UI.

trans-unit.source: Rules for characters limits in the Module elements:
trans-unit.target: Rules for characters limits in the Module elements:

trans-unit.source: The value of the name attribute in the Module element must not exceed 64 characters in length.
trans-unit.target: The value of the name attribute in the Module element must not exceed 64 characters in length.

trans-unit.source: The content of the Description element must not exceed 128 characters in length.
trans-unit.target: The content of the Description element must not exceed 128 characters in length.

trans-unit.source: The content of the Owner element must not exceed 32 characters in length.
trans-unit.target: The content of the Owner element must not exceed 32 characters in length.

trans-unit.source: ** Indicating whether a module's results are deterministic or nondeterministic
trans-unit.target: ** Indicating whether a module's results are deterministic or nondeterministic

trans-unit.source: By default, all modules are considered to be deterministic.
trans-unit.target: By default, all modules are considered to be deterministic.

trans-unit.source: That is, given an unchanging set of parameters, the module should return the same results each time it is run.
trans-unit.target: That is, given an unchanging set of parameters, the module should return the same results each time it is run.

trans-unit.source: Given this behavior, Azure Machine Learning Studio does not re-run modules marked as deterministic unless a parameter or the input data has changed.
trans-unit.target: Given this behavior, Azure Machine Learning Studio does not re-run modules marked as deterministic unless a parameter or the input data has changed.

trans-unit.source: Cached results are returned resulting in faster experiment execution.
trans-unit.target: Cached results are returned resulting in faster experiment execution.

trans-unit.source: However, if your module uses a function that returns different results each time it is run – for example, RAND or a function that returns the current date or time – you can specify the module as being non-deterministic by setting the optional isDeterministic attribute to false.
trans-unit.target: However, if your module uses a function that returns different results each time it is run – for example, RAND or a function that returns the current date or time – you can specify the module as being non-deterministic by setting the optional isDeterministic attribute to false.

trans-unit.source: The module will be rerun each time the experiment is run, even if the module input and parameters have not changed.
trans-unit.target: The module will be rerun each time the experiment is run, even if the module input and parameters have not changed.

trans-unit.source: The Language element in your XML definition file is used to specify the custom module language.
trans-unit.target: The Language element in your XML definition file is used to specify the custom module language.

trans-unit.source: Currently, R is the only supported language.
trans-unit.target: Currently, R is the only supported language.

trans-unit.source: The value of the sourceFile attribute must be the name of the R file that contains the function to call when the module is run.
trans-unit.target: The value of the sourceFile attribute must be the name of the R file that contains the function to call when the module is run.

trans-unit.source: This file must be part of the zip package.
trans-unit.target: This file must be part of the zip package.

trans-unit.source: The value of the entryPoint attribute is the name of the function being called and must match a valid function defined with in the source file.
trans-unit.target: The value of the entryPoint attribute is the name of the function being called and must match a valid function defined with in the source file.

trans-unit.source: The input and output ports for a custom module are specified in child elements of the Ports section of the XML definition file.
trans-unit.target: The input and output ports for a custom module are specified in child elements of the Ports section of the XML definition file.

trans-unit.source: The order of these elements determines the layout experienced (UX) by users.
trans-unit.target: The order of these elements determines the layout experienced (UX) by users.

trans-unit.source: The first child input or output listed in the Ports element of the XML file will be the left-most input port in the Machine Learning UX.
trans-unit.target: The first child input or output listed in the Ports element of the XML file will be the left-most input port in the Machine Learning UX.

trans-unit.source: Each input and output port may have an optional Description child element that specifies the text shown when a user hovers the mouse cursor over the port in the Machine Learning UI.
trans-unit.target: Each input and output port may have an optional Description child element that specifies the text shown when a user hovers the mouse cursor over the port in the Machine Learning UI.

trans-unit.source: Ports Rules:
trans-unit.target: Ports Rules:

trans-unit.source: Maximum number of input and output ports is 8 for each.
trans-unit.target: Maximum number of input and output ports is 8 for each.

trans-unit.source: Input ports allow users to pass data to your R function and workspace.
trans-unit.target: Input ports allow users to pass data to your R function and workspace.

trans-unit.source: The data types that are supported for input ports are as follows:
trans-unit.target: The data types that are supported for input ports are as follows:

trans-unit.source: DataTable: This type is passed to your R function as a data.frame.
trans-unit.target: DataTable: This type is passed to your R function as a data.frame.

trans-unit.source: In fact, any types (for example, CSV files or ARFF files) that are supported by Machine Learning and that are compatible with DataTable are converted to a data.frame automatically.
trans-unit.target: In fact, any types (for example, CSV files or ARFF files) that are supported by Machine Learning and that are compatible with DataTable are converted to a data.frame automatically.

trans-unit.source: The id attribute associated with each DataTable input port must have a unique value and this value must match its corresponding named parameter in your R function.
trans-unit.target: The id attribute associated with each DataTable input port must have a unique value and this value must match its corresponding named parameter in your R function.

trans-unit.source: Optional DataTable ports that are not passed as input in an experiment will have the value NULL passed to the R function and optional zip ports will be ignored if the input is not connected.
trans-unit.target: Optional DataTable ports that are not passed as input in an experiment will have the value NULL passed to the R function and optional zip ports will be ignored if the input is not connected.

trans-unit.source: The isOptional attribute is optional for both the DataTable and Zip types and is false by default.
trans-unit.target: The isOptional attribute is optional for both the DataTable and Zip types and is false by default.

trans-unit.source: Zip: Custom modules can accept a zip file as input.
trans-unit.target: Zip: Custom modules can accept a zip file as input.

trans-unit.source: This input is unpacked into the R working directory of your function
trans-unit.target: This input is unpacked into the R working directory of your function

trans-unit.source: For custom R modules, the id for a Zip port does not have to match any parameters of the R function since the zip file is automatically extracted to the R working directory.
trans-unit.target: For custom R modules, the id for a Zip port does not have to match any parameters of the R function since the zip file is automatically extracted to the R working directory.

trans-unit.source: Input Rules:
trans-unit.target: Input Rules:

trans-unit.source: The value of the id attribute of the Input element must be a valid R variable name.
trans-unit.target: The value of the id attribute of the Input element must be a valid R variable name.

trans-unit.source: The value of the id attribute of the Input element must not be longer than 64 characters.
trans-unit.target: The value of the id attribute of the Input element must not be longer than 64 characters.

trans-unit.source: The value of the name attribute of the Input element must not be longer than 64 characters.
trans-unit.target: The value of the name attribute of the Input element must not be longer than 64 characters.

trans-unit.source: The content of the Description element must not be longer than 128 characters
trans-unit.target: The content of the Description element must not be longer than 128 characters

trans-unit.source: The value of the type attribute of the Input element must be Zip or DataTable.
trans-unit.target: The value of the type attribute of the Input element must be Zip or DataTable.

trans-unit.source: The value of the isOptional attribute of the Input element is not required (and is false by default when not specified); but if it is specified, it must be true or false.
trans-unit.target: The value of the isOptional attribute of the Input element is not required (and is false by default when not specified); but if it is specified, it must be true or false.

trans-unit.source: Standard output ports: Output ports are mapped to the return values from your R function, which can then be used by subsequent modules.
trans-unit.target: Standard output ports: Output ports are mapped to the return values from your R function, which can then be used by subsequent modules.

trans-unit.source: DataTable is the only standard output port type supported currently.
trans-unit.target: DataTable is the only standard output port type supported currently.

trans-unit.source: (Support for Learners and Transforms is forthcoming.)
trans-unit.target: (Support for Learners and Transforms is forthcoming.)

trans-unit.source: A DataTable output is defined as:
trans-unit.target: A DataTable output is defined as:

trans-unit.source: For outputs in custom R modules, the value of the id attribute does not have to correspond with anything in the R script, but it must be unique.
trans-unit.target: For outputs in custom R modules, the value of the id attribute does not have to correspond with anything in the R script, but it must be unique.

trans-unit.source: For a single module output, the return value from the R function must be a data.frame.
trans-unit.target: For a single module output, the return value from the R function must be a data.frame.

trans-unit.source: In order to output more than one object of a supported data type, the appropriate output ports need to be specified in the XML definition file and the objects need to be returned as a list.
trans-unit.target: In order to output more than one object of a supported data type, the appropriate output ports need to be specified in the XML definition file and the objects need to be returned as a list.

trans-unit.source: The output objects will be assigned to output ports from left to right, reflecting the order in which the objects are placed in the returned list.
trans-unit.target: The output objects will be assigned to output ports from left to right, reflecting the order in which the objects are placed in the returned list.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you want to output dataset, Dataset1, and Dataset2 to output ports dataset, dataset1, and dataset2 from left to right, respectively, then define the output ports in the ‘CustomAddRows.xml’ file as follows:
trans-unit.target: For example, if you want to output dataset, Dataset1, and Dataset2 to output ports dataset, dataset1, and dataset2 from left to right, respectively, then define the output ports in the ‘CustomAddRows.xml’ file as follows:

trans-unit.source: For example, if you want to modify the Custom Add Rows module to output the original two datasets, dataset1, and dataset2, in addition to the new joined dataset dataset (in an order, from left to right, as: dataset, dataset1, dataset2), then define the output ports in the CustomAddRows.xml file as follows:
trans-unit.target: For example, if you want to modify the Custom Add Rows module to output the original two datasets, dataset1, and dataset2, in addition to the new joined dataset dataset (in an order, from left to right, as: dataset, dataset1, dataset2), then define the output ports in the CustomAddRows.xml file as follows:

trans-unit.source: And return the list of objects in a list in the correct order in ‘CustomAddRows.R’:
trans-unit.target: And return the list of objects in a list in the correct order in ‘CustomAddRows.R’:

trans-unit.source: Visualization output: You can also specify an output port of type Visualization which displays the output from the R graphics device and console output.
trans-unit.target: Visualization output: You can also specify an output port of type Visualization which displays the output from the R graphics device and console output.

trans-unit.source: This port is not part of the R function output and does not interfere with the order of the the other output port types.
trans-unit.target: This port is not part of the R function output and does not interfere with the order of the the other output port types.

trans-unit.source: To add a visualization port to the custom modules, add an Output element with a value of Visualization for its type attribute:
trans-unit.target: To add a visualization port to the custom modules, add an Output element with a value of Visualization for its type attribute:

trans-unit.source: Output Rules:
trans-unit.target: Output Rules:

trans-unit.source: The value of the id attribute of the Output element must be a valid R variable name.
trans-unit.target: The value of the id attribute of the Output element must be a valid R variable name.

trans-unit.source: The value of the id attribute of the Output element must not be longer than 32 characters.
trans-unit.target: The value of the id attribute of the Output element must not be longer than 32 characters.

trans-unit.source: The value of the name attribute of the Output element must not be longer than 64 characters.
trans-unit.target: The value of the name attribute of the Output element must not be longer than 64 characters.

trans-unit.source: The value of the type attribute of the Output element must be Visualization.
trans-unit.target: The value of the type attribute of the Output element must be Visualization.

trans-unit.source: Additional data can be passed to the R function via module parameters which are defined in the Arguments element.
trans-unit.target: Additional data can be passed to the R function via module parameters which are defined in the Arguments element.

trans-unit.source: These parameters appear in the right most properties pane of the Machine Learning UI when the module is selected.
trans-unit.target: These parameters appear in the right most properties pane of the Machine Learning UI when the module is selected.

trans-unit.source: Arguments can be any of the supported types or you can create a custom enumeration when needed.
trans-unit.target: Arguments can be any of the supported types or you can create a custom enumeration when needed.

trans-unit.source: Similar to the Ports elements, Arguments elements can have an optional Description element that specifies the text that appears when you hover the mouse over the parameter name.
trans-unit.target: Similar to the Ports elements, Arguments elements can have an optional Description element that specifies the text that appears when you hover the mouse over the parameter name.

trans-unit.source: Optional properties for a module, such as defaultValue, minValue and maxValue can be added to any argument as attributes to a Properties element.
trans-unit.target: Optional properties for a module, such as defaultValue, minValue and maxValue can be added to any argument as attributes to a Properties element.

trans-unit.source: Valid properties for the Properties element depend on the argument type and are describe with the supported argument types below.
trans-unit.target: Valid properties for the Properties element depend on the argument type and are describe with the supported argument types below.

trans-unit.source: As with inputs and outputs, it is critical that each of the parameters have unique id values associated with them.
trans-unit.target: As with inputs and outputs, it is critical that each of the parameters have unique id values associated with them.

trans-unit.source: In addition, the id values must correspond to the named parameters in your R function.
trans-unit.target: In addition, the id values must correspond to the named parameters in your R function.

trans-unit.source: In our quick start example the associated id/parameter was swap.
trans-unit.target: In our quick start example the associated id/parameter was swap.

trans-unit.source: A module parameter is defined using the Arg child element of the Arguments section of the XML definition file.
trans-unit.target: A module parameter is defined using the Arg child element of the Arguments section of the XML definition file.

trans-unit.source: As with the child elements in the Ports section, the ordering of parameters in the Arguments section defines the layout encountered in the UX.
trans-unit.target: As with the child elements in the Ports section, the ordering of parameters in the Arguments section defines the layout encountered in the UX.

trans-unit.source: The parameters appear from top down in the UI in the same order in which they are defined in the XML file.
trans-unit.target: The parameters appear from top down in the UI in the same order in which they are defined in the XML file.

trans-unit.source: The types supported by Machine Learning for parameters are listed below.
trans-unit.target: The types supported by Machine Learning for parameters are listed below.

trans-unit.source: int – an Integer (32-bit) type parameter.
trans-unit.target: int – an Integer (32-bit) type parameter.

trans-unit.source: Optional Properties: min, max and default
trans-unit.target: Optional Properties: min, max and default

trans-unit.source: double – a double type parameter.
trans-unit.target: double – a double type parameter.

trans-unit.source: Optional Properties: min, max and default
trans-unit.target: Optional Properties: min, max and default

trans-unit.source: bool – a Boolean parameter that is represented by a check-box in UX.
trans-unit.target: bool – a Boolean parameter that is represented by a check-box in UX.

trans-unit.source: Optional Properties: default - false if not set
trans-unit.target: Optional Properties: default - false if not set

trans-unit.source: string: a standard string
trans-unit.target: string: a standard string

trans-unit.source: Optional Properties: default and isOptional - An optional string without a default value will be passed as null to the R function if a value is not otherwise provided by a user.
trans-unit.target: Optional Properties: default and isOptional - An optional string without a default value will be passed as null to the R function if a value is not otherwise provided by a user.

trans-unit.source: ColumnPicker: a column selection parameter.
trans-unit.target: ColumnPicker: a column selection parameter.

trans-unit.source: This type renders in the UX as a column chooser.
trans-unit.target: This type renders in the UX as a column chooser.

trans-unit.source: The Property element is used here to specify the id of the port from which columns will be selected, where the target port type must be DataTable.
trans-unit.target: The Property element is used here to specify the id of the port from which columns will be selected, where the target port type must be DataTable.

trans-unit.source: The result of the column selection will be passed to the R function as a list of strings containing the selected column names.
trans-unit.target: The result of the column selection will be passed to the R function as a list of strings containing the selected column names.

trans-unit.source: Required Properties: portId - matches the id of an Input element with type DataTable.
trans-unit.target: Required Properties: portId - matches the id of an Input element with type DataTable.

trans-unit.source: Optional Properties:
trans-unit.target: Optional Properties:

trans-unit.source: allowedTypes - Filter the column types the user can pick from.
trans-unit.target: allowedTypes - Filter the column types the user can pick from.

trans-unit.source: Valid values include:
trans-unit.target: Valid values include:

trans-unit.source: Numeric
trans-unit.target: Numeric

trans-unit.source: Boolean
trans-unit.target: Boolean

trans-unit.source: Categorical
trans-unit.target: Categorical

trans-unit.source: String
trans-unit.target: String

trans-unit.source: Label
trans-unit.target: Label

trans-unit.source: Feature
trans-unit.target: Feature

trans-unit.source: Score
trans-unit.target: Score

trans-unit.source: All
trans-unit.target: All

trans-unit.source: default - Valid default selections for the column picker include:
trans-unit.target: default - Valid default selections for the column picker include:

trans-unit.source: None
trans-unit.target: None

trans-unit.source: NumericFeature
trans-unit.target: NumericFeature

trans-unit.source: NumericLabel
trans-unit.target: NumericLabel

trans-unit.source: NumericScore
trans-unit.target: NumericScore

trans-unit.source: NumericAll
trans-unit.target: NumericAll

trans-unit.source: BooleanFeature
trans-unit.target: BooleanFeature

trans-unit.source: BooleanLabel
trans-unit.target: BooleanLabel

trans-unit.source: BooleanScore
trans-unit.target: BooleanScore

trans-unit.source: BooleanAll
trans-unit.target: BooleanAll

trans-unit.source: CategoricalFeature
trans-unit.target: CategoricalFeature

trans-unit.source: CategoricalLabel
trans-unit.target: CategoricalLabel

trans-unit.source: CategoricalScore
trans-unit.target: CategoricalScore

trans-unit.source: CategoricalAll
trans-unit.target: CategoricalAll

trans-unit.source: StringFeature
trans-unit.target: StringFeature

trans-unit.source: StringLabel
trans-unit.target: StringLabel

trans-unit.source: StringScore
trans-unit.target: StringScore

trans-unit.source: StringAll
trans-unit.target: StringAll

trans-unit.source: AllLabel
trans-unit.target: AllLabel

trans-unit.source: AllFeature
trans-unit.target: AllFeature

trans-unit.source: AllScore
trans-unit.target: AllScore

trans-unit.source: All
trans-unit.target: All

trans-unit.source: DropDown: a user specified enumerated (dropdown) list.
trans-unit.target: DropDown: a user specified enumerated (dropdown) list.

trans-unit.source: The dropdown items are specified within the Properties element using an Item element.
trans-unit.target: The dropdown items are specified within the Properties element using an Item element.

trans-unit.source: The id for each Item must be unique and a valid R variable and the name of the item is both the text that appears to users and the value that is passed to the R function.
trans-unit.target: The id for each Item must be unique and a valid R variable and the name of the item is both the text that appears to users and the value that is passed to the R function.

trans-unit.source: Optional Properties:
trans-unit.target: Optional Properties:

trans-unit.source: default - The value for the default property must correspond with an id value from one of the Item elements.
trans-unit.target: default - The value for the default property must correspond with an id value from one of the Item elements.

trans-unit.source: Any file that is placed in your custom module ZIP file will be available for use during execution time.
trans-unit.target: Any file that is placed in your custom module ZIP file will be available for use during execution time.

trans-unit.source: If there is a directory structure present it will be preserved.
trans-unit.target: If there is a directory structure present it will be preserved.

trans-unit.source: This means that file sourcing will work the same locally and in Azure Machine Learning execution.
trans-unit.target: This means that file sourcing will work the same locally and in Azure Machine Learning execution.

trans-unit.source: Please notice that all files are extracted to ‘src’ directory so all paths should have ‘src/’ prefix.
trans-unit.target: Please notice that all files are extracted to ‘src’ directory so all paths should have ‘src/’ prefix.

trans-unit.source: For example, say you want to remove any rows with NAs from the dataset, and also remove any duplicate rows, before outputting it into CustomAddRows, and you’ve already written an R function that does that in a file RemoveDupNARows.R:
trans-unit.target: For example, say you want to remove any rows with NAs from the dataset, and also remove any duplicate rows, before outputting it into CustomAddRows, and you’ve already written an R function that does that in a file RemoveDupNARows.R:

trans-unit.source: Next, upload a zip file containing ‘CustomAddRows.R’, ‘CustomAddRows.xml’, and ‘RemoveDupNARows.R’ as a custom R module.
trans-unit.target: Next, upload a zip file containing ‘CustomAddRows.R’, ‘CustomAddRows.xml’, and ‘RemoveDupNARows.R’ as a custom R module.

trans-unit.source: The execution environment for the R script uses the same version of R as the Execute R Script module, and can use the same default packages.
trans-unit.target: The execution environment for the R script uses the same version of R as the Execute R Script module, and can use the same default packages.

trans-unit.source: You can add additional R packages to your custom module by including them in the custom module zip package and loading them in your R script as you would in your own R environment.
trans-unit.target: You can add additional R packages to your custom module by including them in the custom module zip package and loading them in your R script as you would in your own R environment.

trans-unit.source: Limitations of the execution environment include:
trans-unit.target: Limitations of the execution environment include:

trans-unit.source: Non-persistent file system: Files written when the custom module is run will not persist across multiple runs of the same module.
trans-unit.target: Non-persistent file system: Files written when the custom module is run will not persist across multiple runs of the same module.

trans-unit.source: No network access
trans-unit.target: No network access
